Helpful scales for maps

These functions are simple wrappers around scale_x_continuous and scale_y_continuous with helpful defaults for plotting longitude and latitude.

scale_x_longitude(ticks = 60, name = "", expand = c(0, 0), ...)

scale_y_longitude(ticks = 60, name = "", expand = c(0, 0), ...)

scale_x_latitude(ticks = 30, name = "", expand = c(0, 0), ...)

scale_y_latitude(ticks = 30, name = "", expand = c(0, 0), ...)

scale_x_level(name = "", expand = c(0, 0), trans = "reverselog", ...)

scale_y_level(name = "", expand = c(0, 0), trans = "reverselog", ...)

Arguments

ticks

spacing between breaks
name

name of the scale
expand

a numeric vector of length two giving multiplicative and additive expansion constants.
...

other arguments passed to scale_x_continuous
trans

either the name of a transformation object, or the object itself

Details

scale_*_longitude assumes that your data is between 0 and 360 but labels it from -180 to 180.

See also

Other ggplot2 helpers: DivideTimeseries, RepeatLon, geom_arrow, geom_contour_fill, geom_vector, reverselog_trans, scale_color_divergent, stat_filter, stat_na

Examples

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(aao[date == date[1]], aes(lon, lat, z = gh)) +
    geom_contour() +
    scale_x_longitude() +
    scale_y_latitude()
